basic_data.name: Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Cremation and Funeral Centres

address.streetAddress: 375 Mt Pleasant Rd At Merton St.

description: Beautiful and peaceful cemetery containing the graves of several notable Canadians.

reviews.title: For a peaceful, beautiful walk, this is the place
text: During the pandemic we came here often, as did many other people. Mt Pleasant Cemetery is more peaceful now that the number of people walking through it has returned to pre-pandemic levels. On a sunny fall afternoon it is as beautiful as ever, Highly recommended.

reviews.title: Peaceful walk
text: With Toronto opening up, the number of people using the cemetery for recreation has clearly dropped steeply. This is all for the good. The coyote we saw did not slink away, and we were the only people who were at the gravestone of William Lyon Mackenzie King and the nearby gravestone of Larry Zolf. A fine walk!

reviews.title: No longer a peaceful resting place for loved ones.
text: Beware if you have loved ones resting at Mount Pleasant.  This cemetery has now become a super busy public park with people walking their dogs, whizzing by on their bikes, pushing their strollers.    The only things missing are vendors selling hotdogs and balloons.  It is no longer a sacred peaceful place to visit when you want to spend remembering your loved ones.  Rude white people stand there gawking at you as you try to perform the simplest of cultural rituals.

reviews.title: Great for walking and thinking
text: We started going here early during the pandemic and have been coming back regularly since then to walk around and look at the grave stones. It is a fine place for contemplation. Today was no exception: an unusually nice and mild autumn afternoon. This time we did not visit the grave of W.L. Mackenzie King but went into the eastern section, where we came across the monument commemorating the crash of AC flight 621 in Woodbridge, ON, in July, 1970. I remember hearing about it the day a happened. Fifty years ago: time does fly.

reviews.title: Great walks any time of the year!
text: Such a great place for walks. I have walked many hundreds of hours in this cemetery, yet still find new things of interests. The grave stones often come with interesting stories, or are just beautiful sculptures. If you have the chance to live nearby, you are lucky to have this peaceful green space for healthy walks all year round. I love that place!!

reviews.title: Great place to run or walk
text: Just a beautiful cemetery to run or walk through any time of the year. Fall is most probably the nicest time as all the trees are in full colour but every season has its charm.

reviews.title: Interesting and beautiful place for a walk
text: The cemetery is large and has many old growth trees that are beautiful year round. In the spring there are blossoms. In the summer a wonderful canopy and in the fall amazing colours. Read up on the history before heading there. Lots of interesting facts and some famous residents. There is also lots of wildlife. Birds, racoons, squirrels and a family of coyotes.

reviews.title: How serene and beautiful
text: My all season beautiful walk in our busy city.
I would just like to add a comment to those people who threat this serene "Park" as a picnic ground, it is a place of solitude and remembrance and should be threated with respect.
Beautifully maintained, amazing selection of trees.
Take a stroll, run, bicycle or brisk walk
Most of all, enjoy all that nature can provide, and threat Mount Pleasant Cemetery with the respect it deserves

reviews.title: The maintenance is top notch.
text: During my recent visit I noticed it is even more beautiful than my previous visits. They have the largest selection of different trees in the world. It was a beautiful place to walk and take in the beauty. There are public washrooms by the administration office near Mt Pleasant Rd.

reviews.title: Calm place for cycling ,walking or maybe having a picnic.
text: This was my first ever trip Solo in Toronto and I enjoyed being all on my own.
Having said this ,I also found people walking around with kids,cycling,jogging or just have a nice picnic on the grass there.
The place is very well maintained and has a sombre feeling altogether. Although, I had expectations of much better tombstone and rock carvings, I was a tad bit disappointed.
You can easily spend 3-4hours there, with the lovely breeze around.

reviews.title: A Relaxing and Educational Stroll
text: Cemeteries are no longer just for the dead.  They are wonderful places to go for relaxing walks.  Mount Pleasant Cemetery is particularly large and lush with plant life.  If you have never been, the Fall season is a perfect time to see this pretty place.  Some of the tombs, monuments and gravestones are very unique and impressive.  Famous people like the Eaton family are buried here.  Can you imagine the monument to an American president who served his country for over twenty years?  William Lyon Mackenzie King was one of the world's longest serving leaders.  He is on our fifty dollar bill.  He is buried here.  See if you can find his grave site.  It is so typically Canadian that his grave site is so modest.  Cherish our country by visiting this cemetery and King's final resting place.

reviews.title: You don't have to die to go here!!!!!
text: Beautifully landscaped cemetery to read a book or enjoy a discrete picnic.  Just north of St Clair subway.

reviews.title: Peace and Tranquility
text: Living across the street many years ago, I used to sit outside on Sunday mornings and listen to the violin player and the trumpet player.  It was a wonderful concert every week.  Returned this year for a peaceful walk,and it was just that.  The area is extremely well maintained.  Famous names.  Just peace and quiet amid a very busy city.  It can be a major walk, a lovely drive, a great bicycle ride - take your pick.
Somewhere to re-charge.

reviews.title: a writer's paradise of names and cityscape.
text: always an interesting place to walk through with friends or family especially if you need a quiet moment or looking for stories ideas, you also can learn some great things about the city and the people buried there.  Can take all day, highly worth it.

reviews.title: Great place for a quiet walk.
text: Lovely place for a walk - many different roads through an arboretum/cemetary.  It's a good history lesson too or some of the original families that settled and established empires in Toronto.  It's well maintained and all the trees are marked as to their variety.  I've even spotted some deer in here too.

reviews.title: Historical cemetery that doubles as a park
text: I visit this cemetery all the time as it is close to my residence and a very pleasant way to spend a few hours. In some portions the graves are over a hundred years old, so you find many gravestones with the names of old Toronto, covered in lichen or disappearing under the grass.  It is interesting that often one sees a family name on a headstone and then "Mother" or "Father" for the individual grave.  There is a lot of history here -a prime minister is here in a modest plot, victims of typhoid, four fire fighters who died fighting a fire downtown, a hidden section where Chinese workers were shunted off to the side, and of course the ostentatious mausoleum for the Eaton family that has lions in front of it. It is extremely well kept with many large mature trees, which makes it a nice place to walk.  One frequently sees joggers, bikers, roller bladders getting in some exercise. The cemetery extends from Yonge Street to Bayview Ave, making a jump over Mt. Pleasant Blvd.  I am usually of the west side and enter thru the gates in the accompanying photo.  These gates can be accessed from the Kay Gardener Beltline, which crosses Yonge Street south of Merton Ave.  There is a wide alley/public access way just east of the large condo at Merton and Yonge.  Also there is car access from Yonge Street further south closer to St. Clair Ave.  Cars can also access the cemetery off of Mt. Pleasant.

reviews.title: Well if you need a good run..other than that
text: Why would you want to come here? It's a beautiful cemetery to run, walk or bike in. Such a relaxing feel in the centre of midtown.

reviews.title: Strange but Beautiful
text: Lovely place to respect the dead, great green spaces, some wildlife, great for a stroll through to clear the mind or even just to see the plants, trees are all labelled with their names and latin name. Highly recommend.

reviews.title: the resting place right in the mid-town
text: the mount pleasant group have few location with this is the original land, hence the land, a burial lot may cost the same as a moderate condo somewhere else in Canada

reviews.title: Go
text: It's a cemetery so feel weird about it being a tourist attractions. However it is a nice green space where you could go for a run or a walk around.

reviews.title: Final resting place to some of the most famous Canadians, and a very pretty walk
text: The Mt Pleasant cemetery has a long history as one od the prettiest, trees cemetaries in Toronto.  It's a perfect place for a stroll, cycle or a run.  The cemetery is connected to the Kaye Gardner belt line and also the Rosedale Ravine path which allows you to visit the Brickworks.  There is hardly a more peaceful tranquil place to chill and take stock of how lucky we are to enjoy its beauty.

reviews.title: Final resting place of many Canadians and others from all over the Globe
text: Peaceful, wonderful walking paths. take some time to visit the different areas such as the area dedicated to Koreans and other ethnicities.  The monument to Stavros is magnificent .
So many variety of trees.

reviews.title: Toronto History
text: A beautiful walk through Mount Pleasant Cemetery is filled with flowers and history.  The walkways are lined by old trees, which are busy with life including squirrels and birds.  Notable Toronto names lie here in tombs and family mausoleums.  It's worth a stroll.

reviews.title: Really
text: How can this even be part of a Topic of things to do in  Toronto???  If you seriously need to go to  cemetary in a different city you have issues.

reviews.title: A very scenic and attractive park with lots of history
text: Of course the cemetery has countless grave stones with lots of historic burials, but it is also a very large and scenic park with extensive trails for strolling and cycling.  It's a great place to escape from the surrounding busy city and traffic.

reviews.title: Decent Cemetery
text: I'm not sure why this is even listed here haha it is just a cemetery what tourist goes to visit one unless they know somebody who is buried there? Be that what it is this is a pretty big and attractive cemetery. The grounds are well kept. But still it is just your regular cemetery, just bigger and with lots of nice grass. Nothing really to see or do it's just a cemetery.

reviews.title: A walking experience
text: It has been several years since I lived in Toronto but when I did, I lived about 3 blocks from the East end of Mt. Pleasant cemetery. I walk thru the cemetery was a great day to achieve mi 10000 steps per day. Beyond that, it was simply a very nice place to walk.

reviews.title: Ideal Garden
text: Mount Pleasant Cemetery is supposed to be a place for the deceased but it is more like a garden for the living. I love to walk through this peaceful place and admire the grave stones reading the names of the deceased and enjoying the flowers, trees and the creatures that live there. It is an alluring place to visit. It is one of the oldest and largest cemetery in Toronto consisting of many acres of land. It stretches from Yonge Street and Merton to St. Clair and Bayview Avenues. It is alive with life. Many creatures live in the cemetery.  There is music concerts in the cemetery every summer. There is nothing to be afraid of.  You do not have to be afraid of the deceased. You can ride our bicycle through the entire cemetery and there is decent roads for cars too. You will have a grand old time visiting this large cemetery. There a places with benches for you to relax and enjoy the scenery. I would like you to be brave and visit this cemetery in mid  Toronto starting from Yonge street to Bayview Avenue. There are many condominiums and apartments bordering the cemetery on Merton Street, Mt. Pleasant, Bayview and St. Clair avenues.  Be Brave.

reviews.title: Peaceful
text: I ride my bike thru this  sprawling cemetery,mature trees ,well keeped gardens as it’s has  quiet  extensive  roadway thru it. I also see people walks there dogs , jog ,or  just slowly walking.I .also fine if I see there is a  funeral burial going on it’s easy to take another path as not to disturb there moments of grief .

reviews.title: For a cemetery it's not at all creepy
text: I don't typically like even walking near cemeteries, however, my friend and I went jogging through and it was actually very pretty. It's well landscaped and is actually used by many for visiting their families, exercise, etc. It's neat just walking through and looking at all of the different names. It's is a huge cemetery, however. I recommend giving yourself ample time, and possibly make sure you're out before it gets dark.... just in case! lol

reviews.title: Beautiful Cemetry
text: Its a beautiful well kept cemetery. There is a water fountain ⛲ and small water fall, you can sit there and relax.
I saw alot of kids and people cycling on Sunday.

reviews.title: Lovely place to go for a walk.
text: I have walked at Mount Pleasant Cemetery many, many times.  It is a great location mid-city.  The cemetery is interesting and there are very few cars.

reviews.title: just a pleasant Sunday walk
text: it is hard to think of a massive size this Cemetery is . how huge the head stones are very pleasant just to walk up and down the little hills and you forget how close you are to a major street

reviews.title: A snapshot of Ontarios' past
text: Visiting a cemetery when on vacation may sound a bit weird, but the guided tours of Mount Pleasant Cemetery gives an unusual and interesting exposure to the Who's Who of Ontario's past. Don't miss the Eaton mausoleum. It looks like the Parthenon.

reviews.title: Tranquil cemetery
text: Beautiful in the fall, when the changing colours of the various trees and bushes are at best. Can walk or bike on the quite and not too busy lanes. Read the monuments of many important Canadians buried here.

reviews.title: Gorgeous Tranquil Arboratum.
text: The best trees in the city. This cemetary boasts a huge space, leafy shady spots, impressive mausoleums and temples to the recently and not so recently departed. Many of the most prominent names in toronto history are represented here. It's not only a beautiful spot to walk or cycle, but also to reflect and relax.

reviews.title: beautiful place for a walk
text: Amazing that such a green, lovely place should exist in the middle of a big city. Some of the graves and their stories are fascinating

reviews.title: I have been walking here all my adult life..
text: go for a bike ride or just a very nice quiet walk.  its so Nice and quiet away from all the cars and noise.

reviews.title: Walk in the historical woods
text: The natural and human history of Toronto can be enjoyed in a leisurely walk in this sprawling cemetery. There are wonderful mature trees of all kinds labeled in this arboretum. Many birds and animals call it home. We even saw a coyote one quiet afternoon. The history - sometimes sad - of Toronto people are plain on headstones. The graves and markers of young children who died in the same year in the early 20th Century are especially poignant.

reviews.title: Truly Wonderful
text: This is one of my favorite places in Toronto. It's immaculately kept, and has a lot of paved  walking paths so it's usable by those with a walker or wheelchair.  It's a quiet place to think or have a lunch.  As a bonus, you can make a game of discovering all the famous people buried there.  Just be respectful
